Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Disjoint NP-Pairs and Structural Properties of Complete Sets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
A (disjoint) NP-pair is a pair of disjoint, nonempty sets in the complexity class NP. The study of disjoint NP-pairs is motivated by their relations to public-key cryptosystems and to propositional proof systems. In particular, answers to questions about existence of NP-hard or P-inseparable NP-pairs informs us about the question of whether secure public-key cryptosystems exist; existence of complete NP-pairs is implied by existence of optimal propositional proof systems. This project will investigate P-inseparable and complete NP-pairs further, in particular whether they can be derived from a hypothesis that is weaker than any of the known ones, and whether existence of these NP-pairs have strong consequences that are unknown before. PI will examine commonly (dis)believed hypotheses in complexity theory such as that NP!=coNP and that PH collapses, and research on their relations to the existence of P-inseparable and complete NP-pairs.

It is important to study structural properties of complete sets because they gives us a better understanding of the computational power of various complexity classes, and also might lead to proofs of separation results in complexity theory. The proposed project will focus on the following structural properties of complete sets:
- Robustness: does a complete set remain complete if certain amount of elements are taken away from the set?
- Autoreducibility: does a complete set reduce to itself via a reduction that does not query on the input string?
- Mitoticity: can a complete set be split into two complete sets?
The proposed project aims to address the remaining open questions regarding these properties especially those having major impact in complexity theory if settled. For example, are EXP-complete sets autoreducible for the truth-table reductions? Solving this problem would either separate EXP from PH, or PSPACE from P.

The proposed project will be implemented at a Hispanic-serving institution and will promote interest among students, especially Hispanic minorities, for research and study in theoretical computer science and for computer science and engineering at large. The project will be part of the ongoing effort in the computer science community to understand the computation limits of computers. All results from the project will be disseminated broadly through conferences and journal publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the computational complexity area of computer science, one of the important research foci is to study properties of the so-called complete sets. Complete sets represent the hardest computation problems with given limits of available resources such as time and space. Study of properties, most commonly structural properties of complete sets, help to gain a better and deeper understanding why the underlined computational problems are hard, meaning in many cases that the solving algorithms, or equivalently computer programs, requires unreasonably large amount of time or storage space making them essentially infeasible. That knowledge certainly contributes to one of the ultimate goals of computer science - the capability of designing an algorithm as efficient as possible or prove that such algorithms do not exist for any well-defined computation problem arising from real world applications. Despite decades of research there are still many computation problems for which we’re lacking this capability.

 

One of the major goals of this project is to continue studying structural properties of complete sets to obtain a deeper insight into the computational hardness of complete sets, and find new feasible approaches to tackle fundamental computation problems. Towards that goal we focused on two important and related properties of complete sets, so-called autoreducibility and mitoticity, which are defined in terms of reductions. Depends on which reduction is used one can define different types of autoreducibilities and mitoticities. It has already been known before this project that many well-known complete sets possess autoreducibility and mitoticity, or are autoreducible and mitotic, respectively, under certain reductions. On the other hand, however, it is widely unknown whether they also possess those two properties under other reductions. Our project contributed to this goal with the following significant results:

-          We proved that complete sets for NP are autoreducible even if we allow computations to err with certain probability. This provides evidence that the previous results that common complete sets are autoreducible will still hold even if we include randomness in the computations.

-          We also proved that indeed autoreducibilities are different from mitoticities for any common reductions weaker than the 1-tt reduction, which is one of the simplest reduction used in computational complexity.

 

We believe that the above results is a significant progress towards a deeper understanding of autoreducibilities and contribute to current knowledge about the topic.

 

Another major goal of this project is to further investigate (existence of) P-inseparable and NP-hard NP-pairs, and in particular whether they can be derived from a hypothesis that is weaker than any of the known ones, and whether existence of these pairs has significant complexity consequences. Due to time and effort limit, the PI was unable to obtain any significant results on this topic but did study the recent literature on or related to disjoint NP-pairs and is updated with the latest development on the topic.

 

Boarder Impact: This project was implemented at a Hispanic-serving institution and was featured on the main web page of institution when awarded. We believe that it helped promoting interest among students, especially Hispanic minorities, for research and study in theoretical computer science and for computer science and engineering at large. We also deem our project part of the ongoing effort in the computer science community to understand the computation limits of computers. Some results from our project have already been disseminated at a professional conference while the rest are still yet to be submitted to conferences and/or journals for publication.
